last_post.content:
Delighted to see that Anton Petrov (@antonpetrov) used my 10 parsecs star map in his new video on nearby potentially habitable exoplanets:

https://youtu.be/U12VPKJciZw

See my 10 parsecs resources page: https://gruze.org/10pc/resources/

title: Session 2 - Regulation in the age of AI

last_post.content: Last was a good panel on regulating #AI with Florian Ostmann, Julia Black, Nick Swanson, and Cosmina Dorobantu at the #TuringInstitute. The importance of international cooperation, modeling risks, and other topics and discussed in detail here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mgzlrIvFLO8 (12/12)

title: Session 4, Public Policy Stage - Online Harms Observatory

last_post.content: Next was an introduction of the Turing Institute's Online Harms Observatory with Bertie Vidgen, Angus Williams, and Hannah Rose Kirk. I'm not sure how well this initiative will do post-Twitter, but still interesting to learn about https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gLLJjh7Y0P0 (11/12)

title: Session 4 - Foundation models: the new kid on the block?

last_post.content: Next was a nice discussion on #LLMs at the #TuringInstitute with Michael Wooldridge, Phil Blunsom, Peter Flach, and Angeliki Lazaridou. No uncritical optimism here, and overall a good overview of the space https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Jlzcl7HKMI (10/12)

title: Allen School Colloquium: Natasha Jaques (Google + UC Berkeley)

last_post.content: Next was an amazing talk by Natasha Jaques on social #ReinforcementLearning and other topics. Coordinating multiple agents is extremely challenging, and getting to robustness around these models is even harder. Also it looks like she got the job! Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oUIsXQsfP-A (9/12) #AI #ML #RL

title: May 5 - Kristina McElheran, University of Toronto, Scarborough and Rotman

last_post.content: Next was a great talk by Kristina McElheran on using large scale #economic #data to assess the impact of predictive #analytics on business #performance at #MIT IDE. With unique data McElheran examines questions around what factors lead companies to gain benefit from these technologies and how large that benefit is. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zq7jwUSLQyg (8/12)

Next was a fascinating talk by Gordon Burtch on the impact of owner social identity signaling on #retailer demand at the #MIT Initiative on the Digital #Economy. The interesting effects of Black and women owned business labels on #Yelp are unpacked here, also incorporating real visit #data to gain further insight into patterns. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pMOjvAEpHqk (7/12)

title: Active human-machine interactions necessary for interpretability -  Isaac Kohane, Harvard University

last_post.content: Next was an important talk from Isaac Kohane on why active human interactions are needed for #AI interpretability at the #AlanTuringInstitute. Kohane goes into great detail about how current statistical models can spectacularly fail and the implications for use and design. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UBSxftxjZPc (6/12)

title: Panel discussion, chaired by Hannah Fry - Interpretability, Safety and Security in AI

last_post.content: Next was a spicy panel discussion on the importance of #AI interpretability and the tradeoffs of #automation with Hannah Fry, Isaac Kohane, Aleksander Madry, Cynthia Rudin, and Manuela Veloso at the #AlanTuringInstitute. I can't say I agree with all the points brought up here, but it's an excellent, vigorous debate. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T8Q-vNAt1cc (5/12)

title: Computational Antitrust in Blockchain Ecosystems (McCaskill, Goanta, Greenwood, ten Seldam)

last_post.content: Next was an interesting conversation on computational #antitrust in #blockchain ecosystems with John McCaskill, @goanta, Dazza Greenwood, and Björn ten Seldam also at #CodeX. The public nature of blockchain transactions does allow for some interesting modeling opportunities which are explored here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jb25Ikh0Ckc (4/12)

title: What To Research in Computational Antitrust

last_post.content: Next was an excellent panel on important research topics in computational antitrust (there are a lot!) with Thibault Schrepel, Teodora Groza, Björn ten Seldam, Aleksandra Wierzbicka, Kirill Ryabtsev, Thaiane Abreu, and Alexandru Șotropa at #StanfordCodex's Computational #Antitrust conference. It's almost impossible to succinctly summarize the variety of topics covered, highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VNbFYOnOaTE (3/12)

First was an intriguing couple of sessions on algorithmic disgorgement and sunsetting robots at the #TechPolicyLab. Figuring out how to regulate #models built on ill-gotten #data and the destruction of pieces of #technology that people can form emotional bonds with are important problems and the rich discussion here examines both from multiple angles. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vTcFtezZ2Ao (2/12) #AI #robotics #ethics #AIEthics
I made a video about my AwesomeWM config and some of my workflow with it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3nseth86JLA

Here's one of my #projects: an audio player (written in #python) for playing music before live events that have a definite start time. It will play the tracks such that they end at the given time, making for a smooth start to the event.

Here's a short demo: https://youtu.be/sWdraAQPzFI

title: I Made a ChatGPT Client For Emacs - AND SO CAN YOU!!

last_post.content: Gavin Freeborn has a 16 minute video showing his code for working with #chatgpt from #emacs https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EgVfurJUdFo

My Emacs configuration file has grown large after more than 20 years of searching for my editor nirvana. More than 1,600 lines of Lisp goodness. This Christmas, I decided to start off from scratch, only adding the lines I truly needed.

After 3-4 days, I had around 500 lines that provided me with everything I needed: Org, XML, YAML, Java, BASH, compile buffer, Magit, nice theme and everything else.

https://youtu.be/WW7LxxrTs5Y

#emacs #orgmode #java #bash #unix

@jimmyhmiller

last_post.content:
Sharing another of my #projects that I've been toiling away slowly over the last month.

Last year around this time, we were trekking in the snow deep winter landscapes in the Himalayas in Nepal. I'd taken a lot of footage, but didn't quite get around to editing it altogether.

As of today, I can say that the project is finally complete, in all it snowy 4k goodness. It was a bit of a learning curve after all these years, but a fun one.

Some interesting stuff I apparently didn't notice the first time in updates to AT&T's terms of service, which you agreed to by continuing to use AT&T. This language is designed to insulate AT&T from liability in the event someone SIM swaps your phone number and uses that to steal your identity, crypto, etc. There's quite a bit of ongoing litigation about this very subject.

https://www.att.com/legal/terms.consumerServiceAgreement.html

"AT&T is not responsible for losses incurred as a result of your or a third-party’s use of your AT&T wireless number or other AT&T Service as a source of authentication or verification in connection with any social media, email, financial, cryptocurrency or other account;"

....."To the greatest extent permitted by law, AT&T is not liable to you for any damages of any kind resulting in any way from:

the installation, maintenance, removal, or technical support of AT&T Services, even if the damage results from the ordinary negligence of our installer or other representative;
any unauthorized access to your AT&T Accounts or AT&T Services (including the use of your AT&T Accounts or AT&T Services to access a third-party account), even if the unauthorized access was the result of ordinary negligence by an AT&T employee, representative, agent, or any person or entity purporting to act on AT&T’s behalf;"

Whew, that's some heavy stuff. Meanwhile, please enjoy this latest SIM-swap rap. h/t @nixonnixoff
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C8CumdZhPIw

title: Tektronix 4054A with Option 30+31 Color Dynamic Vector Graphics Demo

last_post.content: Fascinating demo of a late 1970s vector monitor that functioned something like a modern e-ink display. It has two phosphor colours, green and red, anything drawn in green will persist on the very high resolution screen until it is cleared, where the red needs to be refreshed each frame https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M98VOoGFLL8

title: Session 2, Public Policy Stage - AI for economic policymaking experiences, challenges, opportunities

last_post.content: Last was an enjoyable panel discussion on using #algorithms for economic policymaking with Omar Guerrero, Kathryn Fair, Andrew Jones, Cosmina Dorobantu, and Edward Sherman at the #AlanTuringInstitute. When looking to make an impact, starting with the method (AI) isn't the right call. Rather as many in this panel point out, the idea is to first identify problems and apply the correct tools to them, some of which may involve #AI https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4HNM2Mpcnuk (7/7)

Next was a thorough talk on understanding (old) #Twitter #virality by Filippo Menczer at the #MIT Initiative on the Digital #Economy. This talk gets into the complex interplay between bots, polarization, and #contagion in Twitter #networks. While the days for this kind of research are numbered on current platforms, it's still nice to get insight into how these processes may function. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JAIX0ekFJLQ (6/7)

title: Allen School Colloquium: Xinyun Chen (UC Berkeley)

last_post.content: Next was a nice talk by Xinyun Chen on automated program synthesis. This approach has been getting a lot of attention lately, but I'm curious if the challenges with finding bugs in this code will lead to widespread adoption https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v91HsKRMkF8 (5/7) #AI

title: Digital identity systems and the exclusion of marginalised communities

last_post.content: Next was a fantastic short talk by Marina Meira on digital #identity systems and the exclusions of marginalized communities at #AlanTuringInstitute. While moving more government services online can broaden access for some, this talk nicely uses the case study of #Brazil to that without auditing for harms to fundamental rights that the risks can be quite large. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tR4YQonv_I8 (4/7)

title: The Future of Computational Antitrust (Crane, Gal, Kovacic, Askin, Wierzbicka)

last_post.content: Next was a great panel on the future of computational antitrust with Daniel Crane, Michal Gal, William Kovacic, Jonathan Askin, and Aleksandra Wierzbicka at #StanfordCodex Computational #Antitrust conference. The discussion gets into some meaty points around why computational antitrust is important and how to increase uptake by #regulators. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IA9xLJZDtZU (3/7)

title: Recent progress in predictive inference - Emmanuel Candes, Stanford University

last_post.content: First was an amazing talk by Emmanuel Candes on confidence scores for #MachineLearning #algorithms at #AlanTuringInstitute. This work seems critical for conveying uncertainty to users and building better human/ #AI systems. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FQxpdMME0qU (2/7)

Well my oldest and I made it through unscathed in time to go on our trip to Japan tomorrow! A more relaxed day means that while packing and walking the dogs I was able to listen to a bunch of talks for my #AcademicRunPlaylist!

As a reminder, if you want to view my entire playlist starting from a few weeks ago it's at https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL5FQGISvWBK3gNFqx2eboI8etItUC2MFW (1/7)

December 2, 2022:

In this conversation with James Dolan, I said a bit about things I want to think about.

First, how Laplace transforms reduce to Legendre transforms in a certain limit, which may be the limit where statistical mechanics reduces to classical thermodynamics. It's a kind of 'large number limit' or 'Boltzmann's constant goes to zero' limit. It should also be the limit where the 'tropical rig' shows up.

(1/n)

title: Session 7 - What can AI do for our public good? In conversation with Patrick Vallance

last_post.content: Next was an amazing conversation with Patrick Vallance and @helenzmargetts on incorporating #DataScience and #AI into #government and #policy at the #AlanTuringInstitute. Using the COVID-19 experience as a backdrop, the discussion dives into how #data can change conversations with leaders and other stakeholders and how to drive data #technology #adoption in large #organizations. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ho3ubclheFI (10/11)

title: Session 1, Public Policy Stage - Building the AI Standards Hub

last_post.content: Next was an informative discussion on developing #AI #standards in the #UK with Florian Ostmann, David Cuckow, Stephanie Ifayemi, and Sundeep Bhandari at #AlanTuringInstitute. I'm not exactly sure how this effort is going to shake out, but after this conversation I'll continue to watch with interest https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KjX-hWqGgno (9/11)

Next was a number of excellent panels at the #TechPolicyLab on #AI #ethics in #startups, social #robots, and in general. The last two sessions are particularly great, highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tu5dHsvwrzA (8/11)

title: Professor Jo Guldi: Pseudo history and digital history - The Dangerous art of text mining

last_post.content: Next was a banger from Jo Guldi on the dangerous art of #NLP at #AlanTuringInstitute. This is a must listen, elegantly and emphatically taking down #LLMs and the approach of many technologists to #AI in general. I do take issue with the idea posited that nothing is predictable, I still highly recommend this talk https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-V7WZaUk5oA (7/11)

title: April 14 - Daniel Rock, Wharton School at University of Pennsylvania

last_post.content: Next was a great talk by @danielrock on using #NLP to understand how occupations are evolving over time and the rate of new #work creation at the #MIT Initiative on the Digital #Economy. This work offers a nuanced and deep look into how work is evolving. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5dafVO1CxuY (6/11)

title: Preliminaries in automated red teaming in hardening digital identity management systems

last_post.content: Next was a short talk by Anh Tuan Le on automating #RedTeaming approaches for #identity management system #security at #AlanTuringInstitute. There's a focused on decentralized systems here, which as people in the Q&A pointed out might be infeasible for localities with unreliable internet access, still worth a listen if you're in the space https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wuMCbKptwyQ (5/11)

Next was a nice talk by Azalia Mirhoseini on using #MachineLearning to design computational systems for machine learning! Accelerator-based approaches seem critical for current #ML trends to continue, and it seems likely that methods like this will be essential as complexity and compute costs continue to increase https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jr3FudQpNs0 (4/11)

title: Web3: The Future of Platforms and Business Ecosystems (Scott Kominers)

last_post.content: Next was an interesting talk on the potential of #Web3 to weaken #platform power by @skominers at #StanfordCodeX's Computational #Antitrust Conference. Other work has made me somewhat skeptical of this claim, but it's still intriguing to think about these possibilities https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6qWXV2sYH-U (3/11)

First up was a fantastic talk by Cynthia Dwork on using a theoretical #stats framework to prove #algorithmic #fairness bounds at #AlanTuringInstitute. There are some practical takeaways, but some claims should be taken with a grain of salt as they heavily rely on unrealistic statistical properties and take a techno-solutionist approach to fairness that I think is only one piece of the puzzle https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5jALzHR_50w&t=2s (2/11) #AI #ethics #AIEthics

Bike messenger race („alleycat race“) in Mexico City

https://youtu.be/p4QePMP5jfE

#roadcycling

Stories from the Salish Sea: The Kelp Highway

My good friend Chris Morgan narrated a project for Seattle Aquarium focused on the ecology environments around us here in Puget Sound. I can't recommend this series highly enough. The cinematography (and subject matter) are absolutely amazing.

A great place to start is here: https://youtu.be/jg1M4ZdDiY8

The entire series is here: https://salishsea.seattleaquarium.org

Worth a boost if you love the kelp that sustains our marine environments.

title: Welcome to the Internet - Bo Burnham (from "Inside" -- ALBUM OUT NOW)

last_post.content:
Recent discussions here have reminded me of a song that I, or professors I've TA'ed for, often show to our students.

"Mommy let you use your iPad/ You were barely two/ And it did all the things we designed it to do" always gets to me. I had no role in building the current internet; I grew up working class in the Bronx, I didn't even have internet at home until 2002. But I still feel a certain amount of guilt when I look at my students.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k1BneeJTDcU

title: Pre- KEIO TECHNO-MALL 2022（第2回）「慶應義塾が進める医療ヘルスケア領域のデータベース構築とそれを用いたオープンイノベーションによる事業創出の取り組み」

last_post.content:
興味深い慶応大のヘルスケアイノベーションイベントを見て、参考になりました。

最初に中村先生は明確に日本の高齢者ケア状態を客観的なデータと主観的なデータを組み合わせることによって検討して総合的なヘルスコモンズネットワークモデルを提案しました。このモデルはAIとアルゴリズムを用いて複数なヘルスケア機関と連携してお年寄りの方のために効果的でカスタマイズされたソリューションを提供できるようにできます。心配しているのはデータバイアスなどの課題はあげませんでした。

最後に陣崎先生は「AIホスピタル」のコンセプトについて発表しました。このトークにもいろんな大事なアイデアが説明されて、人材資源が不足している日本でデータを用いて効果的な病院機関が作れるのは必要だと思います。しかしAI倫理はこの活動に大きな影響を与える可能性は高いですので、倫理が最初から研究に盛り込んだ方がいいと思います。

このような研究は日本で行っているのは素晴らしいと思います。このプロジェクトは世界のモデルになれるかもしれませんので、AI倫理が中心的にするべきだと思います

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EuTT7rS_JGU #AI

Next was an informative talk by @PawelAdrjan on global #RemoteWork trends from #Indeed #data at the Digital Futures at #Work Research Centre (Digit). With some thorough caveats at the beginning, this talk nicely reviews where the data appears to show workplace strategy trends settling. Useful for level setting and for #governments, but for organizations this shouldn't influence strategy b/c companies have absolutely no idea what they're doing on #workplace strategy https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KQwmszM8B5U (8/9)

Next was an introduction to #AlanTuringInstitute's #data #justice initiative. This is a good quick summary of the potential harms of #algorithms and data-driven technologies https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HPs1u5aibHM (7/9)

Next was two panel discussions at the #TechPolicyLab's We Robot conference, covering #AI #ethics and #regulation. The panels themselves were great, but a lot of the Q&A was... something https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CeWMlzcc2KE (6/9)

Next was an interesting talk by Steve Tadelis on running an extremely effective ad experiment to increase COVID-19 #vaccination rates at the #MIT Initiative on the Digital #Economy. The effect size here is bonkers, and for the life of me I can't find alternative explanations for how a relatively simple intervention generated such a huge effect. Kudos to the authors! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-0jas3d9Cpg (5/9)

title: Computational Antitrust: Measuring Interlocks in The Life Sciences Industry (Mark Lemley)

last_post.content: Next was a fantastic talk by @marklemley on measuring #board interlocks at #StanfordCodeX's Computational #Antitrust conference. Mapping and analyzing board interlock #networks from publicly company #data seems like a no-brainer for regulators, especially given that much of this activity is illegal! Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kRuOmWbnNp4 (4/9)

Next was an amazing talk by @sarameghanbeery on #ComputerVision for #biodiversity monitoring. The intersection of #CitizenScience, #AIEthics, and partnering with local stakeholders described here is an excellent model for all (also I'm glad it seems that Beery is joining MIT!). Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SDnGCZfBK-w (3/9)

title: Towards safe, reliable and trustworthy AI - Pushmeet Kohli, Google

last_post.content: First up was a nice talk by Pushmeet Kohli on #AI #fairness at the #AlanTuringInstitute. While I dislike the term "superhuman" applied to algos here (knives, after all, have "superhuman" cutting ability), the applications of massive models to #toxicity detection and #ProteinFolding were interesting https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ByhW0LZeu4 (2/9)

Report back from Twitter filter fuzzing.

What Twitter is blocking

Twitter is filtering links to known Mastodon instances, but still allows direct links to joinmastodon.org. The filtering seems to happen whenever Twitter's WYSIWYG editor recognizes a valid domain name and that domain happens to be a known Mastodon instance.
Twitter also allows linking to shortened URLs of mastodon profiles, but only once. Posting the shortened URL a second time doesn't work, implying there's some backend queue service that's checking the Location header of links and flagging the ones redirecting to Mastodon instances.

How to evade the filters

Email address spam evasion techniques work. Replacing '.' with ' . ' or [.] or [dot] all work.
URI encoding the hostname. Replace at least one of the characters in the hostname with it's URI encoded version (ex: . -> %2E, https://infosec.exchange -> https://infosec%2Eexchange). Browsers are smart enough to URI decode anything you copy/paste into the address bar.
data: URIs. Twitter does not seem to check base64 encoded data: URIs. It is possible to create a data:text/html;base64,... base64 encoded HTML URI which can be copied into the address bar and will render as HTML. While Twitter will not render data: URIs (for obvious reasons), you can still copy/paste them (at your own risk, of course).
Base64. This seems silly, but we could communicate freely on Twitter by simply Base64 encoding our tweets. This could be accomplished via some Chrome extension.

Twitter's anti-Mastodon filtering is clown shoes amateur hour.🤡​

Edit: as many have pointed out, adding a Mastodon link to the alt-text of your background image presumably still works, encoding the link as a QR code works, setting your Location or Display Name to your mastodon handle works. I only tested links to Mastodon instances in tweets.
Edit 2: someone setup a link shortening service that explicitly blocks Twitter from checking the links which seems to be working: https://spacekaren.sucks/
Edit 3: Twitter has now formalized it's Mastodon censorship policy: https://help.twitter.com/en/rules-and-policies/social-platforms-policy
Edit 4: now that I'm trending on HN, I should link to this other researcher on YouTube who did a much more in-depth analysis of Twitter's JavaScript and API requests: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oHg5SJYRHA0&t=1s

#twitter #birbsite #censorship #filtering #evasion #elmo #muskrat

I love Adam Neely's explanations of music theory and what it's like to be a jazz musician struggling to make a living in New York. But I wasn't so sure I liked his actual music. I'd call it electronic fusion jazz, with technically sophisticated rhythmic tricks like quintuplets, and clever harmonies and melodies. But it didn't move me.

This song, Bird on a Wing, actually does:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1fVleqrHF0w

(1/n)

So... here is it friends... Several years in the making.

https://youtu.be/tspGVbmMmVA

This is the result of being "in the trenches" debating crypto and blockchain technology with armies of people on Reddit, getting booted from just about every pro-crypto subreddit for having the audacity to ask questions people couldn't/wouldn't answer, or point out flaws in various claims.

#crypto #finance #investing #factchecking #blockchain #mythbusting #fintech

title: The Role of Gender & Inclusion in Development Programming [CID Speaker Series]

last_post.content: Next was an important talk by Muthoni Muriu on developing #gender and #inclusion policies for multinational, mission-driven organizations at #CIDHarvard. Building processes and policies into an organization's #culture and following through when scandals strike or new geographies present a challenge are lessons for all people in #management https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N9uh3YvVDoI (10/12)

title: Are super apps the future of mobile-first Africa? | The Next Wave show S1 Ep6

last_post.content: Next was an exciting discussion on why #SuperApps are emerging in #Africa with Emeka Ajene and Alastair Sussock at #TechCabal. I haven't heard such a coherent discussion of super apps before, and the conversation leaves me increasingly interested in this area of African #tech. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DelrsUkFpEc (9/12)

Next was an intriguing talk by Fang Lee Cooke on bringing the strategic #HR theoretical framework to #GigWork at the Digital Futures at #Work Research Centre (Digit). Gigwork companies are ruthlessly efficient from a myopic perspective here, but connecting the employee view of #employment and development to HR strategy is a nice contribution https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_XxTD_pIfK8 (8/12) #management

Next was an amazing panel on the implications of #ESG shareholder activism with Tara Giunta, Eduardo Gallardo, Peter Michelsen, and Michael Callahan. Universal proxy cards (!), why the current ESG push is different than activism of the past, and how #companies and #boards should plan for this moving forward. This is the next frontier for #PeopleAnalytics IMO. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Of_hpYB8wkU (7/12) #management #business

title: Tech Talk with Barry Friedman: Keeping Personal Data Safe From Law Enforcement

last_post.content: Next was an excellent talk by Barry Friedman on safeguarding personal #data from #LawEnforcement at the #TechPolicyLab. As #police #surveillance increases, this talk explores legal and technical frameworks that can be combined to ensure #privacy while enabling #law enforcement on critical issues. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-0JDzpx3n88 (6/12)

Next was a spicy talk by Damon McCoy on auditing #SocialMedia #platforms at the #MIT Initiative on the Digital #Economy. Getting an independent view of the influence of these platforms is a massive undertaking, and McCoy walks us through this process and how to actually get social media companies to move on the missteps. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jj_LmFno0ow (5/12)

title: Allen School Colloquium: Pang Wei Koh (Stanford University)

last_post.content: Next was an interesting job talk by Pang Wei Koh on reliable #MachineLearning from models all the way to application (it looks like he got the job!) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5tidNjeVG8s (4/12) #AI

title: Computational Antitrust: Antitrust Agencies’ View (Dorrell, Skácelová, Giménez, Westrik, Groza)

last_post.content: Next was a nice roundtable with different #antitrust agencies' detailing current applications of computational antitrust at the #StanfordCodeX Computational Antitrust Conference with David Dorrell, Romana Skácelová, Daniel Westrik, Gerard Gimenez, and Teodora Groza. Lots of variance in the tools being deployed, and I'm looking forward to seeing how these different multinational agencies collaborate in the future https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HPEqIPay3Pg (3/12) #regulation #law

title: (TUA2) Keynote: The rise of model-based data and its implications for social science and policy

last_post.content: First was a phenomenal talk by Seth Spielman on the rise of model-based #data at the #AlanTuringInstitute. Data has never been objective, but this talk explores how the injection of modern #statistics into dataset augmentation creates new issues. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=waiyxVeQ_kI (2/12)

title: REVEALED: Pentagon Psy-Op EXPOSED In Twitter Files | Counter Points

last_post.content:
The new twitter is garbage, and Musk is despicable.

But the old twitter was only less smelly garbage, and the reporting by Lee Fang on how they collaborated with the pentagon to create fake accounts to influence foreign politics is a great example.

Everyone in the US goes bananas when accusing the Russians of doing stuff like this, but when evidence comes of the same thing done by the US — then it's silence.

The underlying reason is clear: most people in the US — republicans and democrats alike — actually think this is justified.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uLK5QP9JKXc

title: A public dialogue on location data ethics

last_post.content: Next was an interesting discussion on the public's view of location #data #ethics at The #AlanTuringInstitute with Skye McCool and Aidan Peppin. Prepare for some surprising results here, illustrating the importance of not assuming we know what the public thinks on tech ethics issues. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hvQuCdSzmfU (9/12)

title: Basic Order: The International Monetary and Financial System Meets Security | Tucker | Part 2 of 2

This will get you thinking, highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sOyiYZU5mdo (6/12)

Next was a talk on reverse engineering computation in the #brain by Matthew Golub. It was extremely interesting to see proof of actual computation in the brain for the first time https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=edtYok4KL7k (4/12)
